intro: Dichanthelium consanguineum, commonly known as the hairy panicgrass, is a perennial grass species native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its tufted growth habit and slender, hairy stems that often grow in open, disturbed habitats. The plant produces small, spikelet-based inflorescences with pale green to brown flowers, typical of the grass family Poaceae. Its leaves are narrow and have a rough texture, with prominent veins running along their length. Dichanthelium consanguineum is often found in sandy or clay soils and is adapted to a variety of environmental conditions.
